q: What are the differences between night terrors and nightmares?
a: Night terrors mainly affect children, while nightmares can affect both children and adults. During a night terror, you may scream, shout, thrash about, jump out of bed, and have your eyes open but not awake. Nightmares are bad dreams that you wake up from and can remember.

q: What are some common causes of night terrors and nightmares?
a: Common causes include being very tired or unwell, sudden noises at night, feeling the need to pee during the night, watching a scary film, feeling stressed, anxious, or worried. Certain medicines, sleep conditions, mental health conditions, and brain conditions can also contribute to night terrors and nightmares.

q: When should I see a GP for night terrors and nightmares?
a: You should see a GP if your child has night terrors several times a night or has them most nights, your child has lots of nightmares about the same thing, or you're having regular nightmares that are affecting your sleep and everyday life.

q: How can I help a child who has night terrors or nightmares?
a: You can try having a relaxing bedtime routine, keep a sleep diary to identify any causes, and try to address any sources of stress or anxiety.

q: What should I do if someone is having a night terror?
a: During a night terror, it's best to stay calm and wait for the person to calm down. Avoid talking to them or trying to stop their movements, unless there is a risk of harm. Trying to wake them up may not be helpful and could upset them further.

q: How can I prevent night terrors from happening?
a: If night terrors occur at the same time every night, you can try waking the person up 15 minutes before the expected time of the night terror for a week. This may sometimes help in preventing the night terrors.

q: What are the treatments for nightmares in adults?
a: The treatment for nightmares in adults depends on the underlying cause. Psychological treatment such as counseling may be recommended for nightmares caused by traumatic events. If there is an underlying sleep condition, management of the condition will usually be part of the treatment.
